Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Fire Whirls on Water: Clean and Efficient Hydrocarbon Combustion

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1507623(Oran)

This project proposes to investigate the potential of fire whirls in cleaning up oil spill on water, as they are believe to be faster, cleaner methods of burning up oil that would otherwise spread over large areas. The understanding gained from the proposed study can help to reduce the environmental impact of an oil spill, which is disastrous for people and fragile wildlife and ecosystems living in these areas are greatly affected. As such it has a tremendous socio-economic impact. Graduate student assistants will be involved in the research under the supervision of the principal investigators.

Oil spill over water poses a very dangerous situation, not only in its impact on ecology but also in its potential of causing large scale fires, which in turn are capable of causing losses in properties and human lives. One method of mitigating the hazards associated with fires over oil (mainly hydrocarbons) spill is, as the PIs propose, is to use fire swirls. Because the swirling motion of the air generate a centripetal force and flow toward the axis of the whirl, the air motion over the water surface would prevent the oil from further spreading into larger areas. In the meantime, the burning and the associated increase in the buoyancy effect further enhances the whirl motion and the effect of preventing oil spread while burning the oil in a smaller area (again, due to the inward motion of the air flow) is amplified. The PIs propose to introduce spills over water over a range of sizes, or areas. The swirling air motion will be initially generated, as in small scale tornado-like phenomenon. The experimental approach includes observing and measuring the air motion both near the fire whirl and water motion on and beneath the surface of water, i.e., the mechanism of prevention of oil spread. The results possess a potential to increase our understanding of both fire whirls and burning over water for safety and spill remediation. Over many different scales, these experiments will provide insight into the controlling parameters that govern both oil spread and combustion of oil and other hydrocarbons in open water which has not been explored before.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project set out to explore the characteristics of fire whirls when formed over water, and identify if any specific use could be formulated for such a configuration. The possibility of reducing emissions from in-situ burns of spilled oil was based on visual observations of lighter smoke emanating from a fire whirl formed accidentally over the ocean.

A small-scale experimental apparatus using two quartz half-cylinders was designed and fabricated at the University of Maryland to create fire whirls. While traditional fire whirls are known to produce an intensification of combustion, experiments led to the discovery of a new regime of the fire whirl, dubbed the “blue whirl,” which produced conditions that were significantly more efficient than traditional fire whirls. This state was observed to burn liquid fuels (poured over the water surface) directly without producing soot. With the worldwide need to reduce emissions from both wanted and unwanted combustion, discovery of this new state points to new pathways for highly efficient and low-emission energy conversion and in-situ fuel-spill clean-up.

Further investigations were conducted to study the properties of the blue whirl and what caused it to take on this unique state. This included measurement of the temperature distribution and location of the combustion front. In addition, the conditions for generating this blue whirl regime were experimentally identified using high-speed videography, and underlying fluid mechanics principles have been identified. These results have provided a foundation to develop a theory of the structure of the blue whirl. The project has also given the researchers an opportunity to use novel and fascinating techniques in the investigation.

Results have been published in a journal (PNAS), and also been presented at conferences (10th US NCM, 12th IAFSS) in 2017. The videos and images obtained over the course of the project have been used by multiple media outlets to inform the general public about the discovery of the blue whirl. Based on current knowledge of the phenomenon, some applications have been proposed including oil spill clean-up and more efficient means of combustion. Numerous opportunities for future research have also been identified.
